Arkanızda kovalayan bir katil yapmanız gereken 5 adet jeneratör ve açmanız gereken bir kapı ve bu tek çıkış yolunuz. İşte gerilim işte korku. 

Oyuna gelirsek perks yani karakterinize oyun içi para ile açabileceğiniz bazı özellikler var. Oyunun grafikleri güzel ama güncelleme ile hudu sevmedim. Katil çeşitliliği çok aynı şekilde katillerinde perksleri var. Fizikler yerinde. Yani çok söylenecek bir şey yok. Korku gerilim diyebilirim. Katil de gerçek insan olduğu için gerilim tabi haliyle üst seviyede.

(Bir çıkış yolu daha var herkes ölürse ve tek kalırsanız acil çıkış kapağı var oradan çıkabilirsiniz. Jeneratör tamir etmeden.)
The game is very fun to play and easy to pick up. the ranking in the game means you never get bored of playing the game because you get better as you rank up
Tolles Spiel

Kupiłem grę jeszcze w wersji 2.0 gdy wychodził jeden z pierwszych licencjonowanych killerów. W grze wcielamy się w Surwa lub killera. Zabójca musi zabić jak najwięcej ocalałych a oni równolegle muszą nie dać się zabić i uciec przez bramy lub właz. Gra na przestrzeni lat przeszła wiele zmian. Tych dobrych oraz moim zdaniem tych nie za bardzo przemyślanych. Zmian takie jak modyfikacja poprawiająca mechaniki zrzucania palet, nowe animacje, end game i wiele innych. Są one zrozumiałe lecz na przestrzeni tych wszystkich aktualizacji widać że próg wejścia do gry nowych graczy znacząco się podniósł. 

Nie mówię że gra jest kompletnie nie zalecana gdy nie grasz po kilkanaście godzin tygodniowo tylko to że jest ona zupełnie inna od tej, w którą grałem kilka lat temu i znacząco bardziej skomplikowana. Takie rozwiązania są okej ale czy nie potrzebujemy prostoty w takich grach? Rozumiem że wprowadzanie zmian nawet tych drastycznych jest potrzebne by zachęcić nowych graczy oraz weteranów którzy przestali grać aby znowu zajrzeli i sprawdzili nowości. Jednak gdy twórca ciągle dodaje do gry coś nowego zupełnie zmieniającego mechanikę danej rzeczy jest dosyć frustrująca dla osoby która nie gra w nią ciągle.

Bardzo dużym plusem jest ciągłe dodawanie nowych postaci oraz map licencjonowanych. Gdy piszę tę recenzję posiadam w grze około 700h i nie jestem zły straconego czasu jednak częstotliwość gry spadała w prost proporcjonalnie do wprowadzanych aktualizacji. Grę polecam dla wszystkich miłośników horrorów i tych którzy chcą zobaczyć postać z danego horroru w postaci grywalnego zabójcy lub pobawić się w ucieczkę razem z przyjaciółmi.

[b]Dead by Daylight[/b]—an asymmetric action survival horror game; unique and the only of its kind.
(Note: Any readers of this review will need minimal knowledge of DbD to understand certain used terminology).


[b][h1]The Pros -[/h1][/b]
1. [b]Niche but Loved Game-Play.[/b] 
⠀⠀⠀[i]Dead by Daylight[/i] (DbD) gameplay is original, so much that there is no other multiplayer survival-horror game that has yet to popularly replicate it. There are other competitors out there like [i]Home Sweet Home: Survive, Friday the 13th, Deceit, Last Year: The Nightmare,[/i] and more. However these games, despite being hyped with large(ish) player bases on release, have failed to keep popularity and players; unlike DbD which averages 30,000-40,000 players a day since March 2020 (averaged a minimum of 15k+ players since its 2016 release and with consistent growth per month). Although once DbD has been played thoroughly, like any repetition based game, game-play can get tedious and dry. However, Behavior Studios counters this factor through new (usually purchasable) DLC releases around every 2 months.
⠀⠀⠀There is also a fulfilling reward system to game-play, earning Iridescent Shards and Blood Points to further progress your Survivor/Killer level (up to level 150 after max 3 Prestige) and unlock new perks. There is also a Ranking System (for skill-based matchmaking) that functions through a tally-mark system, starting at Rank 20 up to Rank 1; this Rank resets (differently depending on your acquired Rank that season) on the 13th of each month.

2.  [b]Graphics, Sound, and Optimization[/b]
⠀⠀⠀DbD has never lacked in it's graphics department, whether that be in environment, lighting, shadows, or models. The music and audio is commendable with good clarity and integration. BHVR Studios has also been rolling out map graphic overhauls for almost a year now, further increasing the horror element and visual beauty of its maps. BHVR even did an engine overhaul to Unreal Engine 4 a couple years back, further modernizing the game. However, with these graphic improvements older survivor and killer models have started to look out-dated. On the topic of audio and music, they have also started implementing unique music themes to Killers both in terror radius and chase music adding more depth to each of their personalities.
⠀⠀⠀DbD is mostly free of bugs, at least game-breaking. Throughout my personal game-play I've encountered few game-breaking or joy-ruining bugs, and those that existed have been speedily patched out. The main issue with bugs I've seen have been in the queue lobby and main-menu overlay, but again, nothing causing too much interference with functionality.

3. [b]Content, Updates, and Dev. Communication[/b]
⠀⠀⠀A topic I've already touched upon, however, BHVR has kept clear communication and planning with their community on their upcoming DLC and updates. They release new content around every 2 months which usually includes 6 new perks, a new killer, a new survivor, and (rarely) a new map which all deepen game-play and occasionally changes the Perk Meta; not to mention limited-time holiday based events. They also have committed patching to fix game-breaking bugs, quality of life changes, balancing game-play, and more. With every new (large) update or strong game-play changes/reworks, they test it first in the PTB (available to all players) to patch out any issues instead of instantly rolling it out to live servers; proof of their strong reliance and communication with their player-base.


[b][h1]The Cons -[/h1][/b]
1.  [b]Prices and Corporate Greed[/b]
⠀⠀⠀Despite the consistent content, updates, and reworking that BHVR pumps out, a new visible issue has appeared: corporate greed. The main prerogative with any business or company, is to make money and grow your consumer base to make more money. However, BHVR originally started on a model of cheaper prices and free DLC ([i]A Lullaby for the Dark, Of Flesh and Mud, The Last Breath, Left Behind[/i]) but has now started charging for every released DLC whether it be copyrighted or original content. This decision would have been originally understandable, until they introduced an in-game micro-transaction shop for the purchase of player cosmetics that range from a minimum of $5.00 to a maximum of $10.00 a-pop; excluding the new $10 battle-pass.
⠀⠀⠀Now you can earn some skins and killers/survivors through the free currency of Iridescent Shards, but one DLC will cost you around 18,000 of them which is an immense amount of game-play. Skins have also started to rule BHVR's content updates and events, with a bundle of skins at usually $10.00-a-piece being released with every update. Holiday Events used to be game-play oriented, where you could earn unique limited-edition cosmetics through new in-game interactions and systems; an orientation which is sadly no longer in-place.

2. [b]Hit-Boxes[/b]
⠀⠀⠀Hit-Boxes—a heavily debated and controversial issue that has [i]Plague[/i]d (haha get it) DbD since its release. Many multiplayer games, especially of the FPS genre, have all struggled with hit-boxes, where one ridiculous looking "hit" or "shot" can [i]ruin[/i] a match and infuriate players. I have played DbD since late 2016 (10 month break taken in 2018) between two different accounts, amassing over 2500 hours; which I know is nothing compared to a lot of other players. In my opinion, DbD takes the cake in the worst Hit-Boxes I've ever seen in any game; and I've been playing all genres of PC games since 2007. One hit in a match can be the difference between life-and-death (or win-and-loss), and when that hit looks like it shouldn't (or should) have gone through, nothing is more maddening.
⠀⠀⠀BHVR has attempted to fix this issue with introducing Dedicated Servers (instead of Client Based) and updating the tick-rate of the game from 30 to 60. These changes have improved Hit-Boxes, however, definitely not fixed them.

3. [b]Cross Play and 3.4.0 Rank-Reset Changes[/b]
⠀⠀⠀This is a topic I'm personally quite passionate about as I feel it has negatively affected my game-play the most. The introduction of cross-play and the rank-reset changes of 2019 have exponentially reduced the player skill-level across all ranks. I have been Rank 1 or within the Red Ranks since sometime in 2017, where I felt this used to mean something and be a representation of skill within DbD. Acquiring Rank 1 means nothing now, and is near a joke. BHVR introduced these changes to combat queue times (which were justifiably quite long) by creating more diversity in Ranks; rather than having minimal people in Red Ranks and the average player in Rank 5+.
⠀⠀⠀However, by introducing Cross-Play and Rank Changes it has made acquiring higher-tier Ranks much easier therefore the skill-level heavily reduced. Cross-Play has done so because console players are just definitively worse than PC players (arguably because they are at a controller to keyboard+mouse disadvantage). Surviving and Killing has never been easier.


[b][h1]Summary -[/h1][/b]
⠀⠀⠀[i]Dead by Daylight[/i] is a unique and thrilling experience, a game where you could dump 100s of hours without growing tired; especially with new content every 2 months to inspire you to play again. DbD in its current state is a mostly healthy and popular game that can addict any new player who is a fan of multiplayer horror survival. However, that's just it, this is only the case for precisely the "new players". As an old player I have failed to adapt to the new DbD, but not due to (if I may be so bold) lack of skill, but due to the monetary and even-player-base changes that have altered DbD so heavily; I enjoyed the challenge and competition DbD offered before. However, the enjoyment I used to have has been sucked out by BHVR's new prerogatives. The original features of DbD which enticed me and many old players in, are no longer there. For the new players I fully recommend this game, but as an old player, I simply cannot.
